titleInfo.title: Letter no.240 of 1856 from Commander Felix Jones, Acting Resident in the Persian Gulf, to Henry Anderson, Secretary to the Government of Bombay

mods.abstract: The letter and its enclosures relate to relations between the Shaikh of Ras-el-Khyma [Ra’s al-Khaymah], Sultan bin Suggur [Sultan bin Saqr], and the British, over the importation of slaves into the Arabian peninsula. Jones writes that Shaikh Sultan has complained about his treatment by the British in relation to the slave trade. Following Jones’s letter is the translation of a letter (folio 215) from Shaikh Sultan to Jones, dated 24 July 1856, in which the complaints are made, with the suggestion that the slave trade exists elsewhere in the ports of the Arabian peninsula as well. A translation of Jones’s reply to Shaikh Sultan (folio 216), dated 16 August 1856, includes Jones’s rejection of Shaikh Sultan’s complaints, with the suggestion that the Shaikh attend to the presence of slaves in his own ports and bazaars.
